qas.question: What branch of theoretical computer science deals with broadly classifying computational problems by difficulty and class of relationship?
By what main attribute are computational problems classified utilizing computational complexity theory?
What is the term for a task that generally lends itself to being solved by a computer?

plausible_answers.text: is a branch of the theory of computation in theoretical computer science that focuses on classifying computational problems

qas.question: What branch of theoretical computer class deals with broadly classifying computational problems by difficulty and class of relationship?
What is understood to be a task that is in principle not amendable to being solved by a computer?
What cannot be solved by mechanical application of mathematical steps?
What is a manual application of mathematical steps?

context: <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b4_0>Computational complexity theory<b4_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> <b3_0>is a branch of the theory of computation in theoretical computer science that focuses on classifying <a2_0>computational problems<b3_0/><a2_0/> according to <a1_1>their <a1_0><a1_2>inherent difficulty<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>, and relating those classes to each other. <a2_1>A <a2_2><b5_0><b6_0>computational problem<b6_0/><b5_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/> is understood to be a task that is in principle amenable to being solved by a computer, which is equivalent to stating that the problem may be solved by mechanical application of mathematical steps, such as an <b7_0>algorithm<b7_0/>.
